field_reports.description:
In 2024, the Amazon is facing an unprecedented environmental crisis due to a combination of extreme drought, deforestation, and wildfires that are affecting both the environment and the local population. Regions such as Barcelos and Santa Isabel do Rio Negro have been without significant rainfall for more than 16 months, which has dried up rivers and left vegetation highly flammable. 

The intensification of the El Niño climate phenomenon: the rainfall pattern has been affected by the phenomenon that warms the waters of the Pacific Ocean. It peaked earlier this year and played a role in the onset of the drought; abnormal warming of the waters of the Tropical North Atlantic – the temperature in the maritime region, which is located above South America, could increase between 1.2 °C and 1.4 °C in 2023 and 2024; Record global temperatures - In July, the world broke the record for the highest temperature ever recorded in history. The scenario creates conditions for stronger heat waves, drastically reduces humidity and creates a favorable environment for the spread of flames, aggravated by the illegal use of fires to clean up deforested areas.

Fires, exacerbated by low humidity and high temperatures, are becoming increasingly difficult to control. The National Institute for Space Research (INPE) reported that despite a 24 per cent decrease in deforestation compared to the previous year, the area of forest affected by fire increased from 10 per cent to 35 per cent in the Amazon. The fires have intensified thanks to what experts call a "criminal strategy": instead of cutting down the forest, illegal invaders set it on fire directly, making it easier for the flames to advance in the middle of very dry vegetation. With 21,289 fires registered until September, this represents an increase of 75% compared to last year, according to the National Institute for Space Research (INPE).

The social impact is significant, with more than 747,000 people directly affected by drought and fires, which have jeopardized the supply of drinking water and the health and safety of the population. Data on injuries, deaths and displaced people are still limited.

In the Amazon, in addition to the fires, municipalities have not rained for almost a year. It is the longest drought on record. On 10/24/04, the level of the Negro River reached 12.66 meters, the lowest since monitoring began in 1902, according to data from the SGB (Geological Survey of Brazil). 

The weather forecast for the coming months is for the dry season to continue, which could further aggravate the situation.
field_reports.summary: BRA: Drought - 11-2024 - Droughts and Fires Florestais

field_reports.description:
The droughts affecting the state of Pará in 2024 have reached alarming levels, surpassing those of 2023, considered until then the worst in history. With rivers at extremely low levels, the situation directly affects traditional communities, commerce and tourism, sectors that employ thousands of people. According to the Climainfo website, low tides are the worst ever recorded, making it difficult to transport goods by river. The state government declared an emergency in September, affecting 38 municipalities and profoundly altering the lives of families who depend on rivers for their livelihoods and economic activity.

The decree considers that the drought is causing serious environmental damage, such as the death and migration of fauna species, the destruction of vegetation due to lack of water and the increased risk of fires, which pollute the air with toxic particles and gases. affecting air quality and contributing to climate change.
The document also highlights the impacts on public health, with respiratory problems worsening due to air pollution caused by fires.
The most affected regions are Araguaia, Bajo Amazonas, Carajás, Guajará, Guamá, Lake Tucuruí, Marajó, Río Caeté, Río Capim, Tapajós, Tocantins and Xingu.

As of July this year, at least 86 municipalities in Pará had declared a state of emergency due to droughts, but currently the state has 38 municipalities with drought decrees in force: Alenquer; Almeirim; Altamira; Anapu; Aveiro; Baião; Bannach; Belterra; Belém; Bom Jesús do Tocantins; Breu Branco; Curuá; Itaituba; Itupiranga; Jacareacanga; Juruti; Monte Alegre; Muaná; Novo Progresso; Oriximiná; Ourém; Pacajá; Pau D'Arco; Ponta de Pedras; Porto de Moz; Prainha; Río María; Santa Cruz do Arari; Santana do Araguaia; Santarém; Senator José Porfírio; São Félix do Xingu; Terra Santa; Trairão; Tucuruí; Vitória do Xingu; Xinguara; Obidos.

The river's descent directly affects the communities that depend on it for their livelihoods. River transport, essential for access to remote areas and for the transport of products, is increasingly limited. In several regions, such as around the community of Boim on the Tapajós River, school transport service providers report extreme difficulties in getting students to school, with episodes of children being carried on their shoulders so as not to miss classes.

The most affected people in the current scenario are the indigenous peoples of Pará and the population of São Félix do Xingu, who are facing great challenges due to fires and drought, which have deeply affected their way of life. With environmental degradation, many rivers and lakes, traditional sources of livelihood, are drying up or fish are becoming scarce. This not only jeopardizes fisheries, but also the food security of their peoples, who depend on this resource to nourish their communities and provide them with hydration, food, and transportation. 

Fires, often caused by agricultural expansion and the unbridled exploitation of natural resources, lead to biodiversity loss and air pollution, making it even more difficult for indigenous communities to survive. Water scarcity and deteriorating ecosystems make hunting and gathering food increasingly difficult.

Today, there are 8,536 people in the city and roundabout of São Félix do Xingu, 30 indigenous villages with about 2,000 indigenous people, 25 villages in Ourilandia do Norte with about 1,800 indigenous people, Aldeia de Bannach with about 150 indigenous people, 20 villages in Cumaru do Norte with around 1,500 indigenous people and Pau Darco with 4 communities of around 500 people, totaling 14,486 PEOPLE who are in a serious situation as they face water and food shortages.
field_reports.summary: BRA: Drought - 11-2024 - Droughts and Fires Florestais

field_reports.description:
Heavy rainfall hit the southernmost state of Rio Grande do Sul between April 29 and May 4, causing the worst climate catastrophe in its history. According to the Brazilian Civil Defense, as of June 10, 478 cities (out of 496) have been impacted and a total of 2,398,255 people have been affected, resulting in 806 injuries and 175 confirmed deaths. The disaster has displaced 422,753 people, of whom 16,128 are still in temporary shelters. 
From 15th June new floods have taken place in Rio Grande do Sul, due to new heavy rains. The Brazilian Civil Defence released a new alert for floods and heavy rains on a large portion of the state – between 16th and 17th June rains reached 30mm in 24h around most of the state, with some areas reaching 60mm. On the night of 16th of June, Brazilian Civil Defence has alerted for new floods in rivers Cai, Cadeia, and Sinos, alerting citizens to evacuate their houses. 
Latest figures from Rio Grande do Sul roads department informed that 64 passages on 33 highways have total or partial closures.  
The city hall of São Luiz Gonzaga, in the Northwest Region of Rio Grande do Sul, declared an emergency after recording damage when it was hit by a micro explosion caused by the rains at the weekend. More than 15 thousand inhabitants were affected, leaving 400 people homeless, in addition to 1.2 thousand properties damaged.
The National Society teams have assessed the situation in one of the riverine communities in São Sebastião do Caí. The teams have identified four shelters with over 100 families. Basic needs include water, First Aid kits, food, and hygiene items.

field_reports.description:
On April 29, 2024, Rio Grande do Sul experienced heavy rains. The rainfall recorded was equivalent to three times the average for this time of year, according to the National Institute of Meteorology (Inmet). The situation lasted until Wednesday (8), with accumulated rainfall of more than 800 millimeters. In total, 446 of the 496 municipalities in RS registered some type of problem, affecting 2.1 million people. The main regions affected by the floods are the Metropolitan, Central, Vale do Rio Pardo, Vale do Taquari and Serra Gaúcha. Civil Defense says there are 125 missing and 806 injured. The organization estimates that there are 618,550 homeless people, 81,170 in shelters and 537,380 displaced. The death toll stands at 143. 

Porto Alegre's Salgado Filho Airport is closed indefinitely. Images show flooded areas in the area.  The forecast of rains for the middle of this week in areas already punished by storms has put the state on alert again.

At the time of writing, there are blockades at 85 points on state highways and 51 on federal highways, totaling 136 traffic disruptions. There are 18 points blocked on the BR-116, in cities in the Sierra, the Metropolitan Region and the Sinos Valley.

The level of the Guaíba in Porto Alegre is 1.63 meters above the flood level. In a measurement made at 2 p.m. on Sunday (12), the level was 4.63 meters. The limit for flooding is 3 meters.

The government has declared a state of calamity, a situation that has been recognized by the federal government. As a result, the state can request federal funds for civil defense actions, such as humanitarian aid, infrastructure reconstruction, and restoration of essential services.

Civil Defense has placed most of the state's river basins at risk of rising waters above flood level.

Meteorologists say the storms occurring in Rio Grande do Sul are a reflection of at least three phenomena occurring in the region, exacerbated by climate change. More rain is forecast in the next 24 hours.

The tragedy in the state is associated with intense wind currents, a corridor of moisture from the Amazon, which increases the strength of rainfall, and an atmospheric blockage due to heat waves.

field_reports.description:
In recent days, Rio Grande do Sul has suffered heavy rainfall. The rainfall recorded is equivalent to three times the average for this time of year, according to the National Institute of Meteorology (Inmet). The forecast is that the situation will continue until Saturday (4) with accumulations that could reach up to 400 millimeters, which would be added to the more than 300 millimeters of rain recorded in the last 4 days. In total, 154 of the 496 municipalities of RS have registered some type of problem, affecting 71,300 people.

The main regions affected by the floods are the Metropolitan, Central, Vale do Rio Pardo, Vale do Taquari and Serra Gaúcha. On Wednesday afternoon (1), the National Geological Survey issued a bulletin indicating a significant rise in the water level in the Taquari River basin by the end of the day. According to the report, in Muçum, the river could reach a level of 30 meters and 27 centimeters, with a flood level of 18 meters. In Estrela and Lajeado, the expected level is 30 meters and 95 centimeters, but there is already flooding at 19 meters.

On Thursday morning (02/05), 30 sections of the federal highway were completely blocked due to the disruption caused by the rain. Another section is partially blocked. On state highways, there are 91 points with total blockades. Another 23 sections have traffic partially restricted. 

Civil Protection says 60 people are missing and 36 injured. The Civil Defense estimates that there are about 14,800 homeless people, 4,645 in shelters and 10,242 displaced. In total, 154 of the 496 municipalities in RS registered some type of problem, affecting 71,300 people. The death toll has risen to 32, and Civil Defense recorded 29 deaths as of Thursday (2). The other three deaths were confirmed by city councils, the Fire Department, the Military Police and local organizations.

field_reports.description:
In the first week of April, Brazil surpassed the mark of 3 million dengue cases in 2024. This figure is the highest ever recorded in the entire historical series of the disease in the country, which dates back to the 2000s. At least 13 states and more than 230 municipalities have declared a state of health emergency. 

We understand that there are many factors that have led to this moment: increase in temperatures and rainfall due to climatic phenomena, inadequate basic sanitation, insufficient number of health workers, low effectiveness of government actions to control Aedes aegypti, discontinuity of actions throughout the year, difficulty for the population to eliminate domestic breeding sites,  mosquito resistance to insecticides and the existence of four serotypes circulating at the same time in the country, which favors reinfections.

The Ministry of Health announced on March 18 that it had set aside R$1.5 billion to help states and municipalities in dengue emergencies and has also taken a series of actions to support the response across the country.

Brazil's southern, southeastern and central-western states have the highest concentration of cases and population, which translates into high numbers. We also identified the situation of communities with greater vulnerabilities (less sanitation and education) as a factor in the increase in cases.

The Unified Health System (SUS) is overloaded and has had to expand its structure for care, diagnosis and control of the mosquito.

field_reports.description:
The Brazilian Red Cross through the Central Organ and the Rio de Janeiro State Branch met in a virtual meeting on 01/15/2024 to establish the scope of joint action during the response and recovery phase of the communities impacted during the heavy rains that hit the state and in particular the north of the municipality of RJ. Through the RJ State DRM Department and the National DRM Department, the first information bulletin was produced, as well as notification through the IFRC GO platform.

Since 14/01/2024, the RJ State Branch has been in contact with local authorities for information and has launched a collection campaign for the following items: Powdered milk and infant diapers; Geriatric diapers; Mineral water; Clothing and footwear (all sizes, women's, men's and children's); Dog and cat food; Bed and bath linen; and Personal hygiene and cleaning material. The RJ State Delegation has already indicated the availability of 200 mattresses and 100 blankets for the community. DNGRD and DEGRD continue to assess needs and develop the Response Plan.

field_reports.description:
El paso de una frente fría, que generó un sistema de bajas presiones, provocó fuertes lluvias en el litoral de Sao Paulo entre el sábado (18) y el domingo (19). La masa de aire se concentró en la región del Litoral Norte y Baixada Santista generando elevadas acumulaciones de precipitaciones.

Tres de las cuatro ciudades del Litoral Norte de São Paulo (São Sebastião, Ilhabela, Caraguatatuba y Ubatuba) tuvieron en las últimas 24 horas el volumen de lluvia previsto para todo el mes de febrero, según datos de la Defensa Civil. En São Sebastião, el volumen en las últimas 24 horas en el domingo fue el doble de la media prevista para el mes.

Las tormentas provocaron inundaciones, corrimientos de tierra y bloquearon tramos de las autopistas Rio-Santos, Mogi-Bertioga y Tamoios. En varios puntos del litoral paulista faltaron el agua, la electricidad y la señal de telefonía móvil.

Más de 600 personas están buscando víctimas, entre bomberos, agentes de Protección Civil y vecinos de la zona. El domingo, los helicópteros de la policía militar tuvieron dificultades para llegar a los puntos más críticos debido al mal tiempo. El Ejército envió aviones para ayudar en las labores.

A través del gobierno del estado, se declaró estado de calamidad y se hizo una primera liberación de recursos de R$ 7 millones para gastos. El gobierno del estado hizo nuevas liberaciones, y el gobierno federal también estuvo dispuesto a aplicar recursos de la Defensa Civil nacional, y también para la parte de vivienda y infraestructura para la reconstrucción de la [carretera] Río-Santos".

Más de 50 habitaciones fueron destruidas generando un impacto de personas sin hogar y desplazadas y se llevarán a cabo acciones para retirar a las familias de las regiones de riesgo generando más personas en situaciones delicadas con sus necesidades humanitarias.
field_reports.summary: BRA: Derrumbe - 2023-02 - Chuvas Torrenciais - Litoral Norte de SP

results.name: BRA: Landslide - 2023-02 - Chuvas Torrentanciis - North Coast of SP
results.summary:
The passage of a cold front, which generated a low pressure system, caused heavy rains on the coast of Sao Paulo between Saturday (18) and Sunday (19). The air mass was concentrated in the region of the North Coast and Baixada Santista, generating high accumulations of rainfall.

Three of the four cities on the North Coast of São Paulo (São Sebastião, Ilhabela, Caraguatatuba and Ubatuba) had in the last 24 hours the volume of rain expected for the entire month of February, according to data from the Civil Defense. In São Sebastião, the volume in the last 24 hours on Sunday was double the average forecast for the month.

The storms caused flooding, landslides and blocked sections of the Rio-Santos, Mogi-Bertioga and Tamoios highways. In several parts of the São Paulo coast, there was a lack of water, electricity and mobile phone signal.

More than 600 people are searching for victims, including firefighters, Civil Protection agents and residents of the area. On Sunday, military police helicopters struggled to reach the hotspots due to bad weather. The Army sent planes to help with the effort.

Through the state government, a state of calamity was declared and a first release of resources of R$ 7 million was made for expenses. The state government made new releases, and the federal government was also willing to apply resources from the national Civil Defense, and also for the housing and infrastructure part for the reconstruction of the Rio-Santos [highway]."

More than 50 rooms were destroyed, generating an impact of homeless and displaced people, and actions will be carried out to remove families from risk regions, generating more people in delicate situations with their humanitarian needs.

field_reports.description: O Órgão Central da Cruz Vermelha Brasileira enviou no primeiro momento, dois membros de Gestão de Riscos e Desastres da Sociedade Nacional para fazer avaliação de necessidades e apoiar dentro do Sistema de Comandos de Incidentes que foi instalado na subseção da Ordem dos Advogados do Brasil, na cidade de Itamaraju, Bahia. Esse primeiro envio foi apoiado pelo Ministério da Cidadania do Governo Federal. Uma campanha de arrecadação foi aberta e todos os Departamentos Nacionais da Cruz Vermelha Brasileira, assim como a Equipe de Resposta Nacional e Coordenadores Estaduais de Gestão de Riscos e Desastres estão de sobreaviso, podendo ser deslocado a qualquer momento em apoio na missão. Ao todo são mais de 321.000 afetados, com 14.272 pessoas desalojadas, 4.810 pessoas desabrigadas, 294 pessoas feridas e 16 mortes, de acordo com os dados do Vigidesastres – Ministério da Saúde em 26 de dezembro de 2021. Relatórios cronológicos da Cruz Vermelha Brasileira, assim como avaliação de necessidades são feitos diariamente, já os relatórios completos e preenchimento da Plataforma Go da Federação Internacional da Cruz Vermelha, são feitos a cada cinco dias. Na manhã do domingo (12), o Governador do Estado da Bahia, Sr. Rui Costa, visitou o Centro de Operações e conheceu o trabalho das organizações envolvidas na resposta ao desastre, e disse que toda ajuda da Cruz Vermelha vai ser fundamental para o atendimento a população. Na tarde de segunda feira (13), a equipe da Cruz Vermelha visitou o distrito de Nova Alegria, que é parte do município de Itamaraju – Bahia, onde foram avaliadas as necessidades e danos após a enchente que atingiu a cidade. Na madrugada do dia 16, houve um aumento do efetivo da Cruz Vermelha Brasileira com a chegada de dois voluntários da filial do Ceará. Durante o início da segunda semana foram construídas quatro ferramentas pela equipe da Cruz Vermelha Brasileira para operacionalização do trabalho dos órgãos envolvidos na Operação. Controle de estoque, condensador de dados, solicitação de apoio logístico, estão entre as ferramentas criadas. Na manhã do dia 18, chegou a Itamaraju o membro da Federação Internacional da Cruz Vermelha, Sr. Rodrigo Cuba. Já no período da tarde chegou em Teixeira de Freitas, o primeiro carregamento insumos de ajuda humanitária da Cruz Vermelha Brasileira para somar no apoio aos afetados pelo desastre. Ao total, a Cruz Vermelha Brasileira já destinou ao estado da Bahia mais de 15,5 toneladas de ajuda humanitária, e mais itens estão previstos para chegar ao estado nas próximas semanas. Um ônibus de vacinação também foi colocado a disposição para apoiar as campanhas de multivacinação. Municípios como Medeiros Neto, Itamaraju e Prado já foram apoiados pela Cruz Vermelha Brasileira, e outros do Extremo Sul estão na agenda para essa semana. Algumas dificuldades de entrega estão sendo causadas por comunidades, cidades e distritos estarem com seus acessos comprometidos. Vale ressaltar, que desde setembro, antes do desastre, a Cruz Vermelha Brasileira já estava atuando no estado, com a doação de mais de 700 cartões alimentação e doação de mais de 150.000 itens de saúde para apoiar os impactos da pandemia causados a população. Com apoio da Federação Internacional da Cruz Vermelha, a instituição também conseguiu aprovação de um Fundo de Emergência para Desastres – DREF (sigla em inglês). Esse apoio será aplicado nos municípios de Jucuruçu e Medeiros Neto, e visam a distribuição de cartões alimentação, doação de filtros, kit cama, e capacitação em primeiros socorros e apoio psicossocial. Hoje a equipe da Cruz Vermelha Brasileira está composta por sete pessoas em diferentes áreas como: gestão de riscos e desastres, logística, primeiros socorros e apoio psicossocial. A previsão é que a Cruz Vermelha Brasileira continue apoiando o estado até março de 2022.

field_reports.description:
Gases da erupção do vulcão caribenho La Sufrière chegaram ao Brasil no domingo (11), e começam a se espalhar na atmosfera no Norte do país. Além disso, os gases já alcançam dois continentes: América e África.

Com efeito, imagens de satélite mostram que dióxido de enxofre (SO2) que emanou da erupção alcançou o Amapá, Roraima e começa a avançar pelo Amazonas e o Pará. 

Nesse sentido, é crucial enfatizar que o dióxido de enxofre está em altitude. Assim, não é percebido visualmente e não oferece risco para os moradores do Norte do Brasil assim como  outras áreas que não sejam as próximas da erupção. 

Desde já se destaca que o registro de dióxido de enxofre vulcânico no Norte do Brasil foi feito pelo sensor TROPOMI ou Tropospheric Monitoring Instrument. O sensor é o espectrômetro que está a bordo do satélite Sentinel 5 Precursor, parte do programa europeu de observação da terra Copernicus.

Atualmente, as cinzas do vulcão estão chegando a até 16 quilômetros de altura. Desse modo, com o vento, gases e cinzas conseguem atingir longas distâncias. Os gases, por exemplo, além do Norte do Brasil, chegaram até a Venezuela, Suriname e Guiana. E, pelo vento, avançam pelo Atlântico já chegaram até a África.

Fonte: MetSul
